comment.brief: Interface for objects that can have a script engine representation
comment.full: Interface for objects that can have a script engine representation

comment.brief: @hide
comment.full: @hide

comment.brief: Compares a value with a set of constants, and activates/deactivates visual trees associated with those constants.
comment.full:
Compares a value with a set of constants, and activates/deactivates visual trees associated with those constants.

`Match` (in conjunction with @Case) is useful when you want to display one of a number of different visuals
based on a certain value. You can think of it like pattern matching and/or switch/case constructs from your
favorite programming language.

## Example

    <JavaScript>
        module.exports = {
            active: "blue"
        };
    </JavaScript>
    <Match Value="{active}">
        <Case String="red">
            <Rectangle Fill="#f00" Height="50" Width="50" />
        </Case>
        <Case String="blue">
            <Rectangle Fill="#00f" Height="50" Width="50" />
        </Case>
    </Match>

comment.brief: Specifies the value that will be matched on as a boolean.
comment.full: Specifies the value that will be matched on as a boolean.

comment.full: Specifies the value that will be matched on.

comment.brief: The `ux:Global` attribute creates a global resource that is accessible everywhere in UX markup.
comment.full:
The `ux:Global` attribute creates a global resource that is accessible everywhere in UX markup.

See @Resources for more information.

The `ux:Global` attribute on an UX element creates a single object (singleton) that is globally available.
Using this attribute will prevent the object from being inserted by default the object at its defined location
in the UX tree.

comment.brief: Creates a new Match
comment.full: Creates a new Match

comment.brief:
The context parent is the semantic parent of this node. It is where non-UI structure should
be resolved, like looking for the DataContext, a Navigation, or other semantic item.
comment.full:
The context parent is the semantic parent of this node. It is where non-UI structure should
be resolved, like looking for the DataContext, a Navigation, or other semantic item.

comment.brief:
Whether rooting for this node is completed.
Returns false if unrooting has started.
comment.full:
Whether rooting for this node is completed.
Returns false if unrooting has started.

comment.brief:
Whether rooting of this node has started.
Note that even if this property returns true, rooting may not yet be
completed for the node. See also @IsRootingCompleted.
comment.full:
Whether rooting of this node has started.
Note that even if this property returns true, rooting may not yet be
completed for the node. See also @IsRootingCompleted.

comment.brief: The parent @Visual of this node. Will return null if the node is not rooted.
comment.full: The parent @Visual of this node. Will return null if the node is not rooted.

comment.brief: A linked list holding data for extrinsic properties.
comment.full: A linked list holding data for extrinsic properties.

comment.brief:
Finds the first node with a given name that satisfies the given acceptor.
The serach algorithm works as follows: Nodes in the subtree are matched first, then
it matches the nodes in the subtrees ofthe ancestor nodes by turn all the way to the
root. If no matching node is found, the function returns null.
comment.full:
Finds the first node with a given name that satisfies the given acceptor.
The serach algorithm works as follows: Nodes in the subtree are matched first, then
it matches the nodes in the subtrees ofthe ancestor nodes by turn all the way to the
root. If no matching node is found, the function returns null.

comment.brief: Returns the next sibling node of the given type.
comment.full: Returns the next sibling node of the given type.

comment.brief: If you override `OnRooted` you must call `base.OnRooted()` first in your derived class. No other processing should happen first, otherwise you might end up in an undefined state.
comment.full: If you override `OnRooted` you must call `base.OnRooted()` first in your derived class. No other processing should happen first, otherwise you might end up in an undefined state.
